pages.transcription:
147 x
The Dark Castle
Strong drink is raging.
Prov. 20 1
Behold, a castle in our midst
And dark its portals are:
Strong drink is written on its gates
And Many Enter there.
The Demon sits upon his throne
And rules with pitiless hand:
To wrench the joys of home & heart
And shadow all the land.

The castle has no happy hearts.
For joy it does not bring:
It offers but the cup of drink
That hides a deadly sting.
We cannot count the captives there
Within the castle gates:
And who are held by love of drink
Where woe & death awaits.
The castle has its revels dark,
Its oft-repeated fray:
Its bitter curse: its lifted hand,
Whel life is swept away:
The castle has its broken hearts:
Its bitter tears of woe:
Its awful deeds & reunited souls
As all its records show.

Oh, n e who love the temprance cause,
Aris3e! for duty calls:
Arise! & storm the castle dark-
Its turrets & its walls.
Break down the barriers in the way,
And there, step boldly in:
To rescue Those in peril there,
Around the cups of sin
Give cheer to all who sorrow there,
And bid them hope again:
And show the Demon on his throne,
That he must cease to reign.
There, strike for God: for truth & right:
And let your blows resound:
Nor falter til the castle walls
Are level with the ground!
E.A. Barnes.

The Day is Ended.
The day is ended & I rest
From weary task & care:
To meditate O Lord on thee,
Whose gifts I freely share.
The holy name in light & love
To guide me in Thy ways:
And so I lift, O Lord, to them
My evening hymns of praise.
The day is ended, & I read
The Word That is divine:
It sweetly speaks, O Lord of Thee
And to this sul of mine.
I kneel to lift my evening prayer
On wings of faith & love: 
Tis sweet to ask, O Lord of Thee,
Who answers from above.

The day is ended & tis sweet
To praise & read & pray:
Rejoice still, O Lord in Thee
The guardian of my way.
I lay me down in peace to sleep
Amid the shades of night
I trust myself, O Lord to thee
Until the morning light.
E.A. Barnes

Dreaming of my Darling.
I am dreaming of my darling.
As the evening shades appear:
And a vision comes before me
That a lover holds so clear.
I can feel her gentle presence
Sharing o'er my mourning heart.
Like a dream of love & beauty
Thriss of rapture to impart.
Cho:
I am dreaming of my darling
fairer maid I would not see:
Dreaming mid the twilight shadows
and the dream is sweet to me
over.

On her brow so pure & gentle
Rests a crown of roses bright:
And the jewel on her bosom
Glistens in the fading light.
Radiant smiles of love & greeting
Linger o'er her beaming face:
And she seems in all her beauty
Wailing for my fond embrace.
As the sweetest gift of Heaven:
As the star above my way
She will come & softly linger,
Mid the shades of dying day.
Then a maiden's kiss bestowing
She will lay her hand in mine:
As she whispers low & sweetly-
"I am Thine, forever Thine."
E.A. Barnes.

See notes about this song.
among my papers:
A small package.

Drink No More

Drink no more my friend
From the cup of sin:
For  words can never tell.
All the woe therein
Death is in The cup.
That too many seek:
Then, heed the warning words
That to you I speak-
Drink no more!

Drink no more my friend.
Tis a deadly thing:
It gives a rudy gleam
But is a bitter sting.
'Tis the bane of life:
'Tis a curse indeed:
Oh do not turn away
So with you I plead-
Drink no more!

Drink no more my friend
Share an awful fate
And break from fetters dark
Ere it be too late.
Look to God for help:
Sign the pledge to-day:
And heed my warning words,
Heed them all I pray-
Drink no more!
E.A. Barnes.

Early Prayer.
Long ere the silent night,
Fades out before the day;
The Savior, as with burdened soul,
Goes forth alone to pray.
He seeks a quiet spot,
He meets the Father there;
And lo! amid the solitude,
Lifts up an early prayer.
Since Jesus came to be
A pattren and a guide;
This instance is a lesson sweet -
Too sweet to put aside.

It teaches one and all.
'Mid daily toil and care;
That they begin each coming day,
By seeking Good in prayer.
E. A. Barnes,
St Mark. 1-35

Ere the Roses Bloom Again.
"
-A Song-
"
Yes, the happy spring is here,
With its gifts so sweet and free;
And I hold the pretty rise,
That you kindly bring to me.
But my life is ebbing fast,
Love and skill are all in vain;
You will bear me to my grave,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.

Seated at my open door,
I hear the robins sing;
See the tender birds and leaves;
Feel the balming breath of spring.
But the Angel soon will come.
Render ties to break in twains;
You will miss my face and form,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Here I see the wooded hills,
And the meadows all so green;
Here I see the sunny skies,
Smiling o'er the vernal scene.
Often do I long to stay, -
Foolish wish and all in vain,
I shall sleep to wake on high,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.
E.A. Barnes.

Ere the Roses Bloom Again.
-A Song-
yes the happy spring is here,
With its gifts so sweet and free;
And I hold the pretty rose,
That you kindly gave to me.
But my life is ebbing fast,
Love and skill are all in vain;
You will bear me to my grave,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.
[erased--over]

Seated at my open door,
I can hear the robins sing;
See the tender buds and leaves,
Feel the balming breath of spring.
But the Angel soon will come,
Tender ties to break in twain,
You will miss my face and form,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Here I see the wooded hills,
And the meadows all so green;
Here I see the sunny skies,
Smiling over the vernal scene.
Often do I long to stay, --
Foolish wish and all in vain;
I shall sleep to wake on high,
Ere the roses bloom again.
Ere they bloom again,
Ere the roses bloom again.
E.A. Barnes.

Eventide.
As life is oft a rugged sea.
And billows rise on every side;
'Tis sweet to know by faith in God.
That peace will come eventide.
Cho =
Eventide = Eventide =
At the golden eventide.
All will be well with you and me,
At the golden eventide.

As shadows fall along the way.
Life's sunny beams to dim and hide;
'Tis sweet to say, within the heart,
That light will come at eventide.
As tears of grief are often shed,
And faith, at times, is something tried;
'Tis sweet to say, within the soul,
That joy will come at eventide.
As life will bring its toil and care,
And which, tis vain, to put a-side;
'Tis sweet to know by faith in God,
That rest will come at eventide.
E.A. Barnes.

"Everywhere"
Pro: 15-3.
They look from above as we are told,
The good and the evil, to thus behold;
To note, in our record, the [dross] and the gold,
The eyes of the Lord are everywhere.
They follow our steps, along the way;
And closely they watch us, go where we may,
To note all our doings, by night and by day,
The eyes of the Lord are everywhere.
Then, let us all strive, to do the right,
And bear Him a record, noble and bright,
For watching and keeping us even in sight,
The eyes of the Lord are everywhere.
E.A. Barnes.

The Eye of God.
" "
The eye of God. It looketh down
From yonder throne of light;
It taketh note of what we do,
And keeps us in its sight.
There's not a spot on land or sea,
Beneath the boundless sky;
Where we may turn and thus escape
From God's all-seeing eye.

When we are led to do the wrong,
However small the deed;
There's stern displeasure in the eye,
And which 'tis well to heed.
Where we are led to do the right,
And thus His words obey;
There's sweet approval in the eye,
That beams upon our way.
The eye of God. It taketh not.
Of all our actions here;
It seeth what we are at heart,
And not as we appear.
Then, let the record of our life
Be good and bright and true;
Since in the searching eye of God,
'Tis held in constant view.
E.A. Barnes.

Father.
Father, oh, Father,
Look upon my sadness,
Lift each dark cloud,
That shadows along gladness.
Father, oh, Father,
Se my deep contrition;
Bow down Thy ear,
And heed my soul's petition.

Father, oh, Father,
Be Thou always near me,
Show forth Thy love,
And let Thy precepts cheer me.
Father, oh, Father,
Let Thy grace be given;
Blot out my sin,
And make me fit for Heaven.
E.A. Barnes.

Father
Father, oh, Father,
Look upon my sadness,
Lift each dark cloud,
That shadow all my gladness.
Father, oh, Father,
See my deep contrition;
Bow down Thine ear,
And heed my soul's petition.

Father, oh, Father, 
Be Thou always near me, 
Show forth Thy love, 
And let Thy precepts cheer me, 
Father, of, Father, 
Let Thy grace be given, 
Blot out my sin, 
And make me fit for Heaven.

First a Christian
"And all these things shall be added unto you."
Matt:6:33.
First, a working Christian, 
Serving well the Master too:
Then, the things for which you toil,
Will be added unto you. 
First, a humble Christian,
Happy is your spirit too:
Then, the things for which you hope,
Will be added unto you.

First a praising Christian, 
Keeping all His precepts too:
Then the things for which you ask, 
Will be added unto you.
First a patient Christian, 
Trusting in Him promise too:
Then the things for which yo wait, 
Will be added unto you.
E.A. Barnes

Forever with the Lord
Beyond this world of strife, 
There is a happy band;
Beyond this present life, 
There is a happy band, 
It's home is full of light;
It's robes are pure & bright;
Redeemed, to reign in glory, 
Forever with the Lord.
Beyond this transient day, 
There is a happy band, 
Beyond this rugged way, 
There is a happy band,
It worships at His feet;
It joins the anthems sweet;
Redeemed to reign in glory,
Forever with the Lord.
E. A. Barnes

Forget me Not.
-Song-
I know that all my love is vain, 
For you have told me this;
You thrust upon my asking heart,
A broken dream of bliss.
And yet, as here we meet alone, 
In this secluded spot;
Tis mine to ask, my only love,
That you forget me not,
Forget me not.

I know that we must walk apart,
Or meet as strangers meet;
'Tis best, since all my sweetest hopes,
Lay blighted at my feet,
But while I bear, & that alone,
The bitter pains & blot;
I ask by all the happy past.
That you forget me not,-
Forget me not.
I do not ask a parting kiss, 
I will not take your hand;
My love is like a bloted page,
And so will ever stand.
But ere we part & turn away
From this familiar spot;
I ask again my first lost love,
That you forget me not-
Forget me not.
E.A. Barnes

duplicate page?
Forget me Not.
-Song-
I know that all my love is vain, 
For you have told me this;
You thrust upon my asking heart,
A broken dream of bliss.
And yet, as here we meet alone, 
In this secluded spot;
Tis mine to ask, my only love,
That you forget me not,

duplicated page
I know that we must walk apart,
Or meet as strangers meet;
'Tis best, since all my sweetest hopes,
Lay blighted at my feet,
But while I bear, & that alone,
The bitter pains & blot;
I ask by all the happy past.
That you forget me not,-
Forget me not.
I do not ask a parting kiss, 
I will not take your hand;
My love is like a bloted page,
And so will ever stand.
But ere we part & turn away
From this familiar spot;

Found in Jesus.
Grace is found in Jesus,
Grace that is for all;
The grace that saves by faith in Him. 
If we will heed His call.
Hope is found in Jesus,
Peace of heart & mind;
By Him we have the peace of God,
Which is so sweet and kind.

Life is found in Jesus,
Life, in worlds above;
The golden crown beyond the cross,
That speaks His dying love.
All is found in Jesus,
All these gifts divine;
Oh! come to-day, and freely take,
What is so freely thine.
E.A. Barnes.

X
A Friendly Word.
" " "
"I 'am twenty-one" a young man said,
"And my heart is light and free,
To-day I start on the journey of life,
To solve what it has for me."
[erased- "] An old man heard these hopeful words,
And gravely shook his head;
Then, laying his hand on the speaker's arm,
He kindly and wisely said --
"I have a word to speak, my son,
Just a friendly word to speak,
Before you start on the journey of life,
All its hidden paths to seek."
"Life does not always hold its spring,
For there comes the autumn day;
How youth will fade and the circling years
Will render you old and gray."

"The path's not always rough and dark,
No more than 'tis smooth and bright,
To-day you will walk where the shadows lie,
But to-morrow in the light."
"'Tis now a grief and now a joy,
That we all are sure to meet;
Since the cup of life for one and for all,
Has its bitter and its sweet."
"You'll often meet the tempter, too,
Wherever you chance to go
And it will strive to lure you, step by step,
To the depths of sin and woe."
"But put your trust in God, my son,
And cherish the good and true,
Then His hand will bless and your soul shall live,
For above the vaulted blue."
E.A. Barnes.

"Give Me A Rose" 
The garden smiles in ..... light
And makes a picture all so fair
With walks and trees and flowers sweet
To scent the evening air
We see an old man at his work
With garden tools and ready hands
And there outside the wicket gate
A little maiden stands
The child takes in the garden scene
Where much of bloom and beauty grows
And then we hear her softly say 
"Please, sir, give me a rose?"

He sees her in the fading light
As at the gate she stands alone
And then he speaks so kindly too
"A rose my little one."
He quickly leaves his garden tools, 
And for the gift he goes in ......
And all the while she watches him
With childish eager muse
He goes among the flowers sweet
That soon will take the evening dew
And soon he picks a full red rose
With buds and leaf lets too

See, honor, wealth & home,
Hope, life & happiness,
That drifting on are lost beneath
That dark abyss.
And hear the orphan's cry;
The beggar's bitter tale;
And what is deeper, sadder still-
A woman's wail.
God speed the temperance cause,
And bless it, far & near,
Until the tyrant of the land
Shall disappear
E.A. Barnes.

Going Home
"I am going home," a school-boy said,
As he left his tasks at school.
"To the cottage white on a quiet street.
To the circle of home that is still complete.
And with love for ots golden rule."
"I am going home," a captain said,
As his ship sped o'er the sea,
"To the red farm-house on the lone hillside,
To the sweet village belle, my own promised bride,
And who is now awaiting for me."
"I am going home," a merchant said,
As he left the busy street,
"To the "marble front," on a handsome square,
To my wife, as its queen, in her beauty fair,
And my daughters, so gay & sweet."
over

"I am going home," a woodman said,
As he left his fallen tree.
"To the humble cot just over the hill.
Where my life floweth on like a gentle rill,
With the loved ones so dear to me."
"I am going home," a soldier said,
As he left the battle plain.
"To the dear old home in a northern state,
Where to-day, in their love, all my dear ones wait.
Who will welcome me back again."
"I am going home," a Christian said,
As his life was well nigh o'er,
"To my Father's house by the crystal sea,
For the crown & the robe there waiting for me,
And to wear them forever more."
E.A. Barnes.

Life is before us, love
So bright and fair:
Sweet are the pleasures, love
That we will share.
Here, as I lisp tiny name:
Here, till we meet again:
Kiss me, good night, my love.
Kiss me, good night:

              Good night, my love.

My dream of beauty, love,
Is all in thee:
And thou art dearer, love
Than life to me.
Here, with thy hand in mine:
Here, with my love for thine:
Kiss me, good night, my love,
Kiss me, good night:

              Good night, my love.

E. A. Barnes

Jesus Riegns in Heaven.
John:: 14: 3.
Jesus Riegns in Heaven,
Where his praises ever ring:
Where the sainted see His beauty.
And rejoice that He is king.
Cho:
Jesus riengs,l: Jesus riegns:
In realms of life, on the other side.
And where He is: There we shall be,
For He is our hope & guide.

We Meet Again
We meet again as Christians
Rejoicing in the Lord: 
We come to praise and worship
And hear the gospel word
We trust that He will meet us 
In spirit and in love
As here we seek His blessing
And call on Him above
We meet again as Christians
In answer to His call
And may this hour of worship
Be precious to us all
We come to ask of Jesus
Renewals of His grace
That we may serve Him better
In our appointed place
E.A. Barnes
